repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab and Sind Agricultural
            Extension and Adaptive Research (Phase 2) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the second phase of the
            Punjab and Sind Agricultural Extension and Adaptive Research
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its specific objectives, institutional development
            was partially successful, sustainability is uncertain, and
            both the Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily. A few
            key lessons that can be learned from this project are: 1)
            project success is dependent on management's
            commitment, leadership, vision, technical expertise,
            managerial, and organizational skills; 2) in the future, an
            improved extension program should only be expanded at the
            rate at which suitably trained staff become available to
            implement it efficiently; 3) within the extension system,
            there should be more incentives and merit-based promotional
            opportunities for front-line extension workers; 4) adaptive
            research should be concentrated on farmers' fields
            rather than on stations, not duplicate research done by
            research institutes, be demand-driven, and be designed to
            permit valid economic comparisons of new technologies with
            current farmer practices; 5) farmer education programs
            should be expanded, including special programs for women
            farmers; and 6) the importance of M & E, especially the
            use of appropriate evaluation procedures, to ensure
            efficient, effective, and relevant extension services has
            been reinforced.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab and Sind Agricultural
            Extension and Adaptive Research (Phase Two) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of this second phase of
            the Sind and Punjab Agricultural Extension Project is to
            achieve sustained increases in agricultural production in
            the Punjab and Sind provinces.  For this purpose the project
            would complete the strengthening and reorganization of the
            extension services in Punjab and Sind by extending the
            training and visit system to the remaining 31 districts not
            covered by the two Phase-I projects (Credits 813 and 922),
            while at the same time consolidating the gains made during
            these projects and strengthening the adaptive research
            system in the two provinces.  To achieve these objectives,
            the project would include: 1) agricultural extension
            services (1,600 additional staff and necessary physical
            components, including offices, staff housing, vehicles and
            equipment); 2) adaptive research (3 adaptive research
            farms); 3) staff training; 4) information and media; and, 5)
            project administration, monitoring and evaluation.
            Technical assistance would be provided to support these activities.

Pakistan - Punjab and Sind Agricultural
            Extension and Adaptive Research (Phase Two) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of this second phase of
            the Sind and Punjab Agricultural Extension Phase Project is
            to achieve sustained increases in agricultural production in
            the Punjab and Sind provinces.  For this purpose the project
            would complete the strengthening and reorganization of the
            extension services in Punjab and Sind by extending the
            training and visit system to the remaining 31 districts not
            covered by the two Phase-I projects (Credits 813 and 922),
            while at the same time consolidating the gains made during
            these projects and strengthening the adaptive research
            system in the two provinces.  To achieve these objectives,
            the project would include: 1) agricultural extension
            services (1,600 additional staff and necessary physical
            components, including offices, staff housing, vehicles and
            equipment); 2) adaptive research (3 adaptive research
            farms); 3) staff training; 4) information and media; and, 5)
            project administration, monitoring and evaluation.
            Technical assistance would be provided to support these activities.
